title: Aerobic Exercise for Alzheimer's Disease Prevention in At-Risk Middle-Aged Adults
description_brief: The purpose of the aeRobic Exercise and Cognitive Health (REACH) study is to understand how an aerobic exercise intervention might help promote brain health and cognition, thereby delaying the onset of clinical symptoms of Alzheimer's disease.
description_detailed:
The prevalence and costs associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) are projected to increase exponentially owing to the unprecedented expansion in the elderly segment of the United States' population. Given this looming specter, delaying the onset of AD symptoms and curbing the progression of the underlying disease process has become a national public health imperative. Delaying symptom onset by as little as 5 years could reduce the prevalence of AD by half. Unfortunately, currently available drug treatments for AD are not curative. Similarly, clinical trials testing novel disease-modifying therapeutics have been disappointing. The urgency of alternative approaches for halting the global crisis posed by AD cannot be overstated.

Animal studies have demonstrated that aerobic exercise (EXER) is a low-cost, low-risk intervention capable of altering the AD pathological process. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of EXER in older adults have also revealed its beneficial effects on AD-relevant measures such as brain glucose metabolism and memory/executive function. Importantly, a recent evidence review found that of 7 key modifiable risk factors for AD, physical activity had the highest impact on reducing the national prevalence of AD. However, there are presently no RCTs examining the effects of EXER in middle-aged, asymptomatic individuals at increased risk of AD. This is an important knowledge gap for several reasons. Interventions to halt the AD pathological cascade are more likely to be effective if implemented prior to pervasive neuronal damage. Secondly, persons with specific risk factors for developing AD (such as parental family history (FH)) represent a choice target population for any credible attempts at reducing the growing burden of AD. Lastly, a key limitation of prior EXER RCTs is the failure to adequately account for participants' physical activity levels outside of the intervention.

Accordingly, the main objective of this study is to pilot a 26-week trial of EXER among asymptomatic, middle-aged adults with and without family history (FH) of AD enrolled in the Wisconsin Registry for Alzheimer's Prevention (WRAP) or the Wisconsin Alzheimer's Disease Research Center (WADRC). The investigators' near-term goal is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of this structured intervention and preliminarily evaluate (i) its effect on AD-relevant outcomes such as glucose metabolism and (ii) the mechanism for such effects. The investigators' longer-term goal is to use the data gathered via this pilot to further refine the intervention, estimate effect sizes for key outcomes, and seek NIH funding for a longer and more definitive assessment of whether EXER can effectively curtail AD progression in midlife. The specific aims are:

AIM 1: Determine the feasibility and acceptability of a 26-week, 3-4 days per week, structured EXER regimen among middle-aged adults with FH of AD. Hypothesis: The investigators will successfully enroll the 30 participants (15 each in EXER and usual physical activity groups) targeted for this study. At least 90% of the participants within the EXER group, called the enhanced physical activity group, will complete ≥80% of scheduled training sessions.

AIM 2: Preliminarily characterize the effect of the EXER intervention on AD-related brain alteration. Hypothesis: Compared to participants randomized to the usual physical activity group, those randomized to the enhanced physical activity group will demonstrate preserved brain glucose metabolism. Similar effects will be seen in secondary outcomes including cerebral blood flow, hippocampal volume, vascular health, memory/executive function, and mood.

AIM 3: Preliminarily evaluate (i) the biological mechanisms by which EXER affects brain health and cognition, and (ii) the individual difference factors that potentially moderate EXER's effects. Hypotheses: (i) Persons in the enhanced physical activity group will exhibit significant increases in circulating neurotrophins and improved cardiorespiratory fitness, and (ii) the beneficial effects of EXER will be more pronounced for participants with decreased sedentary behaviors outside of the intervention (measured via accelerometry).

AIM 4: Preliminarily determine whether EXER improves vascular health. Hypothesis: Individuals in the enhanced physical activity group will exhibit comparatively increased cerebral blood flow, and improved endothelial function.

groups.title: Usual Physical Activity
groups.description: Usual Physical Activity: Participants in this group will receive education from study staff about the importance of maintaining a healthy and active lifestyle. They will receive standardized literature such as "Exercise \& Physical Activity: Your Everyday Guide from the National Institute on Aging". These booklets provide vetted and reliable information for older adults on how to exercise. Participants assigned to the usual physical activity group will not be provided additional support or guidance with an exercise program.

groups.title: Enhanced Physical Activity
groups.description: Enhanced Physical Activity: Participants in this group will engage in a 26-week treadmill walking aerobic exercise intervention. The initial speed and duration will be calibrated to each participant's baseline aerobic capacity. Participants will train 3-4 days per week with the goal of attaining current public health recommendations of 150 minutes of moderate intensity exercise by the 7th week of training and maintaining this level of exercise for the remainder of the 26-week intervention. Exercise will be set at 50-60% of maximum heart rate reserve for weeks 1-4, 60-70% for weeks 5-8, and 70-80% for weeks 9-26. Exercise duration will be 15-20 minutes per session during the first week and then increase by 5 minutes each week until a duration of approximately 38-50 minutes per session is reached. Each training session will begin with a 5-minute warm-up and end with a 5-minute recovery period. Training will occur in individual sessions supervised by exercise specialists.

groups.title: Total
groups.description: Total of all reporting groups

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Number of Participants with APOE e4 positive
measures.description: Apolipoprotein E (APOE) is a protein in the body used to metabolize fat, the presence of the epsilon 4 allele (APOE e4)is correlated to increased Alzheimer's and cardiovascular disease risk.

measures.title: Number of Participants with Parental History of Alzheimer's Disease
MMSE
measures.description: Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is a question scored from 0-30 where scores of 0-17 indicate severe cognitive impairment, 18-23 indicate mild cognitive impairment, and 24-30 indicate no cognitive impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Acceptability: Percentage of Sessions Completed by Enhanced Physical Activity Group
outcomeMeasures.description: This intervention will be considered acceptable if participants who complete the Enhanced Physical Activity intervention, complete ≥80% of scheduled training sessions.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cerebral Glucose Metabolism as Measured by FDG PET Scanning
outcomeMeasures.description: Changes in cerebral glucose metabolism will be assessed using fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET) scanning. This method measures the brain's use of blood sugar while in a resting state. Measurements were taken in the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC). An increase in this measure indicates an increase in the brain's uptake and usage of blood sugar.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.description: Cerebral blood flow velocity changes in the middle cerebral artery will be measured using Transcranial Doppler ultrasound imaging.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: California Verbal Learning Test-II Total Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The California Verbal Learning Test-II assesses cognitive function. Higher scores indicate more words recalled. Scores range from 0 to 100.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: Delis-Kaplan Executive Function System Color Word Interference (D-KEFS CWI) Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The D-KEFS CWI will be used to measure executive function. Lower times indicate improved executive function. Scores range from 0 to 90.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: up to 26 weeks (measured at baseline and 26 weeks)

outcomeMeasures.title: Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) measures global cognitive function. Scores range from 0 to 30. Higher scores indicate better cognitive function.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: up to 26 weeks (assessed at baseline and 26 weeks)

outcomeMeasures.title: California Verbal Learning Test-II Long Delay Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The California Verbal Learning Test-II assesses cognitive function. Long delay is a test where there is a 20 minute time period between initial word list presented and recall. Higher scores indicate more words recalled. Scores range from 0 to 20.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: Profile of Mood States (POMS) Score
outcomeMeasures.description: The Profile of Mood States was used to assess mood. POMS is divided into six subscales including tension-anxiety (9 items, score range: 0-36), depression (15 items, range: 0-60), anger-hostility (12 items, range: 0-48), vigor-activity (8 items, range: 0-32), fatigue (7 items, range: 0-28), and confusion-bewilderment (7 items, range: 0-28). Total mood disturbance is calculated by adding five of the six subscales (Tension, Depression, Anger, Fatigue, and Confusion) and subtracting Vigor (Scores range from -32 to 200). Lower scores typically indicate more steady mood profiles. Higher scores indicate more mood disturbance.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: up to 26 weeks (assessed at baseline and 26 weeks)

outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: up to 26 weeks (assessed at baseline and 26 weeks)

outcomeMeasures.title: Ancillary Neuroimaging Measures
outcomeMeasures.description: Ancillary neuroimaging measures include MRI brain scans of blood flow and brain structure.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: Cardiorespiratory Fitness Measured by Peak Oxygen Consumption (VO2peak)
outcomeMeasures.description: The investigators will examine Cardiorespiratory Fitness by measuring VO2peak on a graded treadmill test - after participants fasted for 12-hours.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor
outcomeMeasures.description: The investigators will examine levels of Brain Derived Neurotrophic Factor to assess changes in blood neurotrophic levels.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor
outcomeMeasures.description: Levels of Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor will be assessed to identify changes in vascular health.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit

outcomeMeasures.title: Arterial Plaque Presence
outcomeMeasures.description: Changes in plaque presence will be measured using Comprehensive Carotid Ultrasound.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: Subclinical Atherosclerosis Burden
outcomeMeasures.description: Changes in subclinical atherosclerosis burden will be measured using Carotid Intima-Media Thickness Ultrasound.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: Endothelial Function
outcomeMeasures.description: Endothelial function changes will be assessed via ultrasound using Brachial Artery Reactivity Testing.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: over 26 weeks (assessed at baseline visit and at week-26 visit)

outcomeMeasures.title: Sedentary Behavior Measured Via Accelerometer
outcomeMeasures.description: Participants wore a triaxial accelerometer (GT3X+, Actigraph LLC, Pensacola, FL) for seven consecutive days to record free-living PA and sedentary behavior before and after the intervention.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: up to 26 weeks (measured at baseline and 26 weeks)

eventGroups.title: Enhanced Physical Activity
eventGroups.description: Enhanced Physical Activity: Participants in this group will engage in a 26-week treadmill walking aerobic exercise intervention. The initial speed and duration will be calibrated to each participant's baseline aerobic capacity. Participants will train 3-4 days per week with the goal of attaining current public health recommendations of 150 minutes of moderate intensity exercise by the 7th week of training and maintaining this level of exercise for the remainder of the 26-week intervention. Exercise will be set at 50-60% of maximum heart rate reserve for weeks 1-4, 60-70% for weeks 5-8, and 70-80% for weeks 9-26. Exercise duration will be 15-20 minutes per session during the first week and then increase by 5 minutes each week until a duration of approximately 38-50 minutes per session is reached. Each training session will begin with a 5-minute warm-up and end with a 5-minute recovery period. Training will occur in individual sessions supervised by exercise specialists.

eventGroups.title: Usual Physical Activity
eventGroups.description: Usual Physical Activity: Participants in this group will receive education from study staff about the importance of maintaining a healthy and active lifestyle. They will receive standardized literature such as "Exercise \& Physical Activity: Your Everyday Guide from the National Institute on Aging". These booklets provide vetted and reliable information for older adults on how to exercise. Participants assigned to the usual physical activity group will not be provided additional support or guidance with an exercise program.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention described (aeRobic Exercise and Cognitive Health — REACH) is an aerobic exercise program intended to promote brain health and cognition and to delay onset of clinical Alzheimer's symptoms. This is a non‑pharmacologic, behavioral intervention aimed at improving cognitive outcomes rather than a biologic or small‑molecule targeting amyloid/tau or a treatment for neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Act (key extracted details): Study title: "Aerobic Exercise for Alzheimer's Disease Prevention in At‑Risk Middle‑Aged Adults" (REACH). Intervention: supervised/individualized aerobic exercise (26 weeks in the pilot protocol). Population: cognitively normal, at‑risk middle‑aged/late‑middle‑aged adults (family/genetic risk). Intended effect: improve/preserve cognition and brain health and delay clinical symptom onset. This is not a drug or biologic—no pharmacologic agent is tested. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Reflect: Given the category definitions, the trial best fits 'Cognitive enhancer' because its primary goal is to improve or preserve cognitive function/brain health (prevention) rather than to target Alzheimer pathology with a biologic or small molecule or to treat neuropsychiatric symptoms. It is a non‑drug, behavioral cognitive‑health intervention; alternative label 'N/A' would apply only if the trial were purely diagnostic or non‑therapeutic, which is not the case here.

• Protocol of Aerobic Exercise and Cognitive Health (REACH): A Pilot Study — PubMed: describes a 26‑week individualized supervised aerobic exercise intervention in cognitively normal but at‑risk adults to inform a larger RCT examining effects on AD biomarkers and cognition. citeturn0search0

• REACH pilot results abstract (Alzheimer's & Dementia conference): RCT pilot of aerobic exercise vs wait‑list in adults at risk for AD showing improved VO2 peak and some cognitive improvements; study used FDG‑PET, MRI and cognitive tests. citeturn0search2

• Systematic reviews / RCT evidence: Meta-analyses and trials indicate aerobic exercise can improve cognitive measures (e.g., executive function) and brain structure/function in adults and in some Alzheimer/dementia studies, supporting the classification as a cognition‑targeting intervention. citeturn0search3turn0search7

Notes / ambiguity: This is a behavioral (exercise) prevention/training intervention rather than a pharmacologic agent; no drug name or placebo is applicable. If you prefer categorical labels that only apply to pharmacologic trials, answer would be 'N/A', but under the provided four categories the best match is 'Cognitive enhancer'.
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is supervised aerobic exercise (a non‑pharmacologic, behavioral prevention/cognition‑enhancement intervention). Aerobic exercise exerts effects across multiple biological systems relevant to CADRO (e.g., synaptic plasticity/neuroprotection, neurogenesis, metabolism/bioenergetics, vasculature, inflammation and growth‑factor signaling such as BDNF) rather than a single molecular target like amyloid or tau.

Act (key extracted details): Study title: "Aerobic Exercise for Alzheimer's Disease Prevention in At‑Risk Middle‑Aged Adults (REACH)". Intervention: individualized supervised aerobic exercise (pilot: ~26 weeks). Population: cognitively normal but at‑risk middle‑aged adults (family/genetic risk). No drug or biologic tested; no single molecular target or pathway specified in the protocol. Given the broad, multisystem biological effects of exercise, the trial maps best to a multi‑target CADRO classification.

Reflect: A single CADRO category such as M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection could partially describe exercise effects, but because aerobic exercise simultaneously impacts multiple CADRO domains (neurogenesis, metabolism, vasculature, inflammation, growth factors, etc.) the most accurate classification is R) Multi‑target. There is insufficient information to assign any single molecular target or pharmacologic mechanism; the intervention is therapeutic/preventive (not diagnostic), so T) Other is not appropriate.
Web search results / supporting sources (provided by user):

• Protocol of Aerobic Exercise and Cognitive Health (REACH): A Pilot Study — PubMed: describes a 26‑week individualized supervised aerobic exercise intervention in cognitively normal but at‑risk adults to inform a larger RCT examining effects on AD biomarkers and cognition.

• REACH pilot results abstract (Alzheimer's & Dementia conference): RCT pilot of aerobic exercise vs wait‑list in adults at risk for AD showing improved VO2 peak and some cognitive improvements; study used FDG‑PET, MRI and cognitive tests.

• Systematic reviews / RCT evidence: Meta‑analyses and trials indicate aerobic exercise can improve cognitive measures (e.g., executive function) and brain structure/function in adults and in some Alzheimer/dementia studies, supporting the characterization of the intervention as cognition‑targeting.
